item.title: Covid: Increasing confidence jabs work against Indian variant
item.description: There is "increasing confidence" Covid vaccines are effective against the variant, Matt Hancock says.

item.title: Heysham explosion: Child dies and four adults injured in Lancashire blast
item.description: Two-year-old George Hinds died in the explosion, which happened in the early hours of Sunday.

item.title: Israel Gaza conflict: Deaths mount in Gaza as UN meeting begins
item.description: The UN Security Council is holding an emergency meeting as mediators try to broker a ceasefire.

item.title: Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer condemn 'shameful' anti-Semitism in video
item.description: Police are investigating after a video appeared to show people shouting anti-Semitic abuse in London.

item.title: Perfectly reasonable for me to forward on PPE offer - Hancock
item.description: The health secretary defends his role in helping a former Tory minister to secure a PPE deal.

item.title: John Kerry: US climate envoy criticised for optimism on clean tech
item.description: John Kerry told the BBC technologies that don't yet exist will play a huge role in stabilising the climate.

item.title: 'World first' as Cambridge vet saves tiger's eye
item.description: Specialist vet says surgery on a tiger takes "a lot more anaesthetic" than on a domestic cat.

item.title: 'Many more arrests' to follow Rangers crowd trouble
item.description: Five police officers were injured and 28 people arrested as trouble flared in Glasgow city centre.

item.title: Myanmar military take rebel town of Mindat, Chinland
item.description: Anti-military activists in the town armed themselves following protests against the February coup.

item.title: Princess Diana: BBC postpones Panorama film on interview with Martin Bashir
item.description: The investigative film has been delayed over a “significant duty of care issue”, the broadcaster says.

item.title: Ben Kielesinski: The man who took the world on an adventure
item.description: Throughout Covid Ben Kielesinski has taken his TikTok followers on trips around Vancouver.

item.title: Covid: Tom Cruise signs shirts for football club on movie set
item.description: The Hollywood star made the gesture to help out a football club raising cash for the community.

item.title: ICYMI: DJ set in the clouds and Harry Potter in NYC
item.description: Here's some news from this week that you might have missed.

item.title: The mid-air walkways saving endangered animals
item.description: Conservationists have built an ingenious system to help the endangered Javan slow loris.

item.title: Property in Wales: Buying a home 'unachievable' for many
item.description: Nearly half the homeowners helped by the Help to Buy scheme earn at least £40,000, a report says.

item.title: Driving Japan's first bullet trains
item.description: The world's fastest ever train was launched in Japan in 1964.

item.title: Fostering: ‘I have fostered more than 60 children
item.description: Patricia Gray always wanted to help other children - but there's a warning fewer people are fostering.

item.title: How Israel's Iron Dome missile shield works
item.description: The Israeli military says the Iron Dome is intercepting about 90% of the rockets fired from Gaza.

item.title: Beverley bullocks: Escaped cattle seen grazing in gardens
item.description: The cattle, which had wandered from nearby fields, were later rounded up and returned home.

item.title: How do you convince people to have babies?
item.description: As China and the US look set to shrink in population, what can they do to encourage people to procreate?

item.title: Israel-Palestinian conflict: False and misleading claims fact-checked
item.description: We examine false and misleading claims from both sides that have been shared widely on social media.

item.title: Torlonia marbles: 'The priceless statues I saw covered in dust and dirt'
item.description: For years a priceless sculpture collection lay hidden behind a door on the staircase leading to David Willey's flat.

item.title: Herdwicks: The 'smiley' sheep that shaped the Lake District
item.description: Saved from demise by Beatrix Potter, the Herdwick breed is synonymous with the lakes' landscape.

item.title: Covid economy: What economists got right (and wrong)
item.description: A year ago, the US economy tanked. Will it return to normal once the pandemic is over?

item.title: Eurovision 2021: How this year's acts are aiming for a Covid-safe contest
item.description: The acts of this year's Eurovision have been navigating a global pandemic to take part in Rotterdam.

item.title: Chelsea women: Why Emma Hayes is the driving force behind success
item.description: The Chelsea women's coach is hoping for a historic win in tonight's Champions League final.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Why doesn't Japan cancel the Games?
item.description: Current polls in Japan show nearly 70% of the population do not want the Olympics to go ahead.

item.title: Keeper Alisson's stoppage-time header keeps Liverpool's top-four fate in own hands
item.description: Goalkeeper Alisson scores an incredible injury-time winner as Liverpool claim a significant victory in their quest to achieve a Premier League top-four finish by coming from behind to beat West Brom.

item.title: Tottenham boost European hopes with win over Wolves
item.description: Tottenham boost their hopes of qualifying for the Europa League with a comfortable Premier League win over Wolves.

item.title: Archer ruled out of New Zealand series with elbow problem
item.description: England fast bowler Jofra Archer is ruled out of the two Tests against New Zealand next month after a recurrence of his elbow problem.

item.title: Chelsea can become European powerhouse, says captain Eriksson
item.description: Chelsea captain Magdalena Eriksson says winning the Women's Champions League final against Barcelona can help the club become "a European powerhouse".

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions have eased in England, Scotland and Wales

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: India variant: Why was India not put on the red list sooner?
item.description: India was put on the travel ban list two weeks after Pakistan and Bangladesh.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel through two south London boroughs are being urged to take a Covid-19 test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to make hugging safer, from the experts
item.description: Millions of people will be able to hug loved ones again from Monday. But can you minimise the risk?

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Concern is growing over a rise in UK coronavirus cases linked to a variant from India.

item.title: Which countries are on the green list for foreign holidays?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible from 17 May, but there are still rules in place.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 38 and 39 in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Indian variant: What's causing the spike in Bolton?
item.description: The town has seen a sharp spike in Covid cases - driven by the emergence of the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 36 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the plans for the NHS app?
item.description: People travelling abroad from England will be able to use the NHS app to prove their Covid vaccination status.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Secondary school pupils in England will no longer be required to wear them in class from next week.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Adoption: 'Our sons' birth family turned them against us'
item.description: There are calls for more support for adoptees - as social media searches for birth families rise.

item.title: St Michael's Mount in Cornwall seeks live-in castle officer
item.description: A love of Cornwall is a must for this job and people who suffer from sea sickness need not apply.

item.title: Victim of 'Elon Musk' Bitcoin scam loses home deposit
item.description: Teacher Julie Bushnell says she lost her deposit for a new home in a cryptocurrency giveaway con.

item.title: China: Man left dangling from bridge after glass breaks
item.description: The tourist was given counselling following his ordeal in a mountainous part of north-eastern China.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Period changes could be a short-term side effect
item.description: Stories of genuine experiences shared online have been followed by a wave of anti-vaccine disinformation.

item.title: Uyghur imams targeted in China's Xinjiang crackdown
item.description: China has targeted Muslim religious leaders, according to a new report, charging many with extremism.

item.title: 'Talk to me': A train driver asking men to open up
item.description: A tragedy inspired Scotland's only woman freight train driver to get men talking about mental health.

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.

item.title: The 'smart and cheeky' Aboriginal boy teaching Australia a lesson
item.description: A film about an Aboriginal boy's experience of school shines a light on Australia's failure to give all children a fair start.

item.title: Joe Ligon: America's 'longest juvenile lifer' on 68 years in prison
item.description: After waiting seven decades for freedom, Joe Ligon tells the BBC how he intends to spend the rest of his days.
